item.title: #TIL : Do not use mutable objects as default parameters
item.description: Do not use mutable objects as default parameters I learned this from learn-python3 Example : def append_if_multiple_of_five(number, magical_list=[]): if number % 5 == 0: magical_list.append(number) return magical_list print(append_if_multiple_of_five(100)) print(append_if_multiple_of_five(105)) print(append_if_multiple_of_five(123)) print(append_if_multiple_of_five(123, [])) print(append_if_multiple_of_five(123)) Result : [100] [100, 105] [100, 105] [] [100, 105] So default parameters in Python is shared between function calls if it isn’t passed from caller. So be careful because shared mutable object can affected your logic between function calls, where MAGIC was born !
